20101229191055.000|20101229191058.000|TR0|SOPHY:  I think you're absolutely right, 
20101229191058.000|20101229191100.000|TR0|we don't have enough studies in children 
20101229191100.000|20101229191103.000|TR0|that will tell us long-term effects of 
20101229191103.000|20101229191105.000|TR0|medications.  That's why if you do land on 
20101229191105.000|20101229191108.000|TR0|medicine as your treatment option and 
20101229191108.000|20101229191110.000|TR0|modality, you really need to build a tight 
20101229191110.000|20101229191113.000|TR0|relationship with that treating physician 
20101229191113.000|20101229191115.000|TR0|so that you're able to go back and forth.
20101229191115.000|20101229191118.000|TR0|
20101229191118.000|20101229191120.000|TR0|Almost on a daily basis with some of my 
20101229191120.000|20101229191123.000|TR0|patients when I start them on medicine, 
20101229191123.000|20101229191125.000|TR0|I'm constantly in contact with parents,

20101229191414.000|20101229191416.000|TR0|
20101229191416.000|20101229191419.000|TR0|HOLMES:  All right.  For centuries, people 
20101229191419.000|20101229191421.000|TR0|have done palm reading, trying to find out 
20101229191421.000|20101229191424.000|TR0|your fate by having your palm read.  Now 
20101229191424.000|20101229191426.000|TR0|we have a rather intriguing study from the 
20101229191426.000|20101229191429.000|TR0|U.K.  It's found a possible link between 
20101229191429.000|20101229191431.000|TR0|the length of your fingers and your 
20101229191431.000|20101229191434.000|TR0|prostate cancer risk.
20101229191434.000|20101229191436.000|TR0|
20101229191436.000|20101229191439.000|TR0|Our senior medical correspondent, 
20101229191439.000|20101229191441.000|TR0|Elizabeth Cohen, joins us now with these 
20101229191441.000|20101229191444.000|TR0|details.
20101229191444.000|20101229191446.000|TR0|
20101229191446.000|20101229191449.000|TR0|Elizabeth, hello to you.
20101229191449.000|20101229191451.000|TR0|
20101229191451.000|20101229191454.000|TR0|So every guy out there needs to take a 
20101229191454.000|20101229191456.000|TR0|peek at their hands and check out what?
20101229191456.000|20101229191459.000|TR0|
20101229191459.000|20101229191501.000|TR0|ELIZABETH COHEN, CNN SENIOR MEDICAL 
20101229191501.000|20101229191504.000|TR0|CORRESPONDENT:  You know, really, I'm 
20101229191504.000|20101229191506.000|TR0|picturing people all across the country, 
20101229191506.000|20101229191509.000|TR0|men going like this and looking at their 
20101229191509.000|20101229191511.000|TR0|hands, because this is really an 
20101229191511.000|20101229191514.000|TR0|intriguing finding.  What it means is 
20101229191514.000|20101229191516.000|TR0|another question.  And we'll get to that 
20101229191516.000|20101229191519.000|TR0|later.
20101229191519.000|20101229191522.000|TR0|
20101229191522.000|20101229191524.000|TR0|But what these researchers in Britain 
20101229191524.000|20101229191527.000|TR0|found, T.J., is that they looked at 
20101229191527.000|20101229191529.000|TR0|hundreds of men, and they looked at the 
20101229191529.000|20101229191532.000|TR0|size, the length, of their index and their 
20101229191532.000|20101229191534.000|TR0|ring fingers, their fingers on other side 
20101229191534.000|20101229191537.000|TR0|of the middle finger.  And what they found 
20101229191537.000|20101229191539.000|TR0|is that when the ring finger was longer 
20101229191539.000|20101229191542.000|TR0|than the index finger, that those men were 
20101229191542.000|20101229191544.000|TR0|more likely to get prostate cancer.  If 
20101229191544.000|20101229191547.000|TR0|the reverse was true, and the index finger 
20101229191547.000|20101229191549.000|TR0|was longer than the ring finger, then they 
20101229191549.000|20101229191552.000|TR0|were 33 percent less likely to get 
20101229191552.000|20101229191554.000|TR0|prostate cancer.
20101229191554.000|20101229191557.000|TR0|
20101229191557.000|20101229191559.000|TR0|It's kind of odd, isn't it?
20101229191559.000|20101229191602.000|TR0|
20101229191602.000|20101229191604.000|TR0|HOLMES:  OK.  Elizabeth, is there a 
20101229191604.000|20101229191607.000|TR0|logical explanation for this?      COHEN:  
20101229191607.000|20101229191609.000|TR0|There is not a truly firm explanation for 
20101229191609.000|20101229191612.000|TR0|this, T.J.  But what there is, is a 
20101229191612.000|20101229191614.000|TR0|theory.  So, since we don't have a good 
20101229191614.000|20101229191617.000|TR0|explanation, we'll go with the theory.
20101229191617.000|20101229191619.000|TR0|
20101229191619.000|20101229191622.000|TR0|The theory is that doctors know -- they 
20101229191622.000|20101229191624.000|TR0|found that men who have prostate cancer 
20101229191624.000|20101229191627.000|TR0|have higher levels of testosterone running 
20101229191627.000|20101229191629.000|TR0|around in their bodies.  Now, another 
20101229191629.000|20101229191632.000|TR0|thing that some studies have found is that 
20101229191632.000|20101229191634.000|TR0|when a mom has high levels of testosterone 
20101229191634.000|20101229191637.000|TR0|in her body when she's pregnant with a 
20101229191637.000|20101229191639.000|TR0|little boy, that those little boys also 
20101229191639.000|20101229191642.000|TR0|tend to have higher ring fingers.
20101229191642.000|20101229191644.000|TR0|
20101229191644.000|20101229191647.000|TR0|And so that's where you get lots of 
20101229191647.000|20101229191649.000|TR0|testosterone in uterus, exposed to it, 
20101229191649.000|20101229191652.000|TR0|that may mean that later on they're going 
20101229191652.000|20101229191655.000|TR0|to have lots of testosterone in their 
20101229191655.000|20101229191657.000|TR0|bodies, which we know puts them at a 
20101229191657.000|20101229191700.000|TR0|higher risk for prostate cancer.  So 
20101229191700.000|20101229191702.000|TR0|that's the theory.  But again, it's just a 
20101229191702.000|20101229191705.000|TR0|theory now, which is why men who have 
20101229191705.000|20101229191707.000|TR0|these longer ring fingers should not be

20101229191710.000|20101229191712.000|TR0|

20101229194546.000|20101229194549.000|TR0|
20101229194549.000|20101229194552.000|TR0|(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)
20101229194552.000|20101229194554.000|TR0|
20101229194554.000|20101229194557.000|TR0|ALLAN CHERNOFF, CNN CORRESPONDENT:  I'm 
20101229194557.000|20101229194559.000|TR0|Allan Chernoff.  The biggest story of the 
20101229194559.000|20101229194602.000|TR0|year had to be the BP oil spill in the 
20101229194602.000|20101229194604.000|TR0|Gulf of Mexico.  As soon as it happened, I 
20101229194604.000|20101229194607.000|TR0|wondered how were they going to clean up 
20101229194607.000|20101229194609.000|TR0|that mess?  I wanted to show viewers 
20101229194609.000|20101229194612.000|TR0|exactly what BP was going to have to do.
20101229194612.000|20101229194614.000|TR0|
20101229194614.000|20101229194617.000|TR0|So I gained access to the government's oil 
20101229194617.000|20101229194619.000|TR0|spill test tank where the energy industry 
20101229194619.000|20101229194622.000|TR0|actually practices for such accidents.  It 
20101229194622.000|20101229194624.000|TR0|was the very first time TV cameras had 
20101229194624.000|20101229194627.000|TR0|ever been permitted into that high

20101229195821.000|20101229195823.000|TR0|two presidents with two groups of armed 
20101229195823.000|20101229195826.000|TR0|supporters.
20101229195826.000|20101229195828.000|TR0|
20101229195828.000|20101229195831.000|TR0|And sadly, this is not a surprising story 
20101229195831.000|20101229195833.000|TR0|in Africa where leaders hold on to power 
20101229195833.000|20101229195836.000|TR0|and civil war seems the norm.  Mugabe and 
20101229195836.000|20101229195838.000|TR0|Zimbabwe comes to mind, as well conflicts 
20101229195838.000|20101229195841.000|TR0|in the DRC, Sierra Leon, Angola, Sudan -- 
20101229195841.000|20101229195843.000|TR0|you name it, just goes on and on.
20101229195843.000|20101229195846.000|TR0|
20101229195846.000|20101229195848.000|TR0|The problems in Africa, of course, are 
20101229195848.000|20101229195851.000|TR0|deep rooted, complex, well documented.  
20101229195851.000|20101229195853.000|TR0|Solutions have been elusive.  But I was 
20101229195853.000|20101229195856.000|TR0|struck by a quote from a Swedish diplomat 
20101229195856.000|20101229195858.000|TR0|in a weekend "New York Times" article.  
20101229195858.000|20101229195901.000|TR0|And he said, quote, "In Africa, when you 
20101229195901.000|20101229195903.000|TR0|are president, you have everything. And 
20101229195903.000|20101229195906.000|TR0|when you are not, you have nothing."
20101229195906.000|20101229195908.000|TR0|
20101229195908.000|20101229195911.000|TR0|Until Africa has a crop of leaders whose 
20101229195911.000|20101229195913.000|TR0|elections lead to prosperity for someone 
20101229195913.000|20101229195916.000|TR0|other than themselves, the story in Cote 
20101229195916.000|20101229195918.000|TR0|d'Ivoire will be repeated, maybe forever.
20101229195918.000|20101229195921.000|TR0|
20101229195921.000|20101229195923.000|TR0|It's time for Brooke Baldwin in the CNN 
20101229195923.000|20101229195926.000|TR0|NEWSROOM now.
